Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF: Unraveling Fluvial Kinematics before the Rise of Land Plants: Bridging Laboratory and Geologic Scales
Award.AbstractNarration: Dr. Jeffery Valenza has been awarded an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and education activities at the University of California Santa Barbara under the mentorship of Dr. Vamsi Ganti, and at Imperial College London under Dr. Alexander Whittaker. This study aims to understand how rivers function in the absence of bank-strengthening vegetation. While nearly all modern river environments are impacted by vegetation, this has only been the case for the most recent ~10% of earth’s history. Prior to the evolution of terrestrial plants, rivers drained the continents without the stabilizing effects of rooted plants, much like extraterrestrial environments on Mars and Titan. The research will characterize the ways that vegetation-free rivers change through time using physical experiments and outcrop analysis. Experiments will focus on discovering conditions that produce a vegetation-free, winding river and will measure the resulting features. These data will be used to characterize and interpret ancient environmental conditions using sandstone exposures in NW Scotland. Bridging laboratory and geologic scales will provide new measures of how pre-vegetation rivers evolved and is applicable to other planetary bodies such as Mars, with preserved river features in an environment with no plants. The project also included outreach and mentoring activities that highlight the laboratory experiments through educational demonstrations and scientific training. Mentoring of undergraduates will be facilitated by the California Alliance for Minority Participation program and mentoring of high-school students and science teachers will be accomplished through the Apprentice Researchers program at University of California Santa Barbara. <br/><br/>An irreversible shift occurred in the rock record of ancient rivers, which coincides with the evolution of land plants during the Silurian period approximately 450 million years ago. This stratigraphic shift was hypothesized to mark the transition from the predominance of shallow, multi-threaded rivers in un-vegetated landscapes to the widespread occurrence of low-gradient meandering rivers that developed due to the bank-stabilizing effect of vegetation. However, recent observations indicate that single-threaded rivers can readily form in barren desert landscapes, and their occurrence is increasingly recognized on extraterrestrial surfaces and from sediments pre-dating the greening of the continents. These observations challenge the paradigm that the Silurian transition in fluvial strata occurred due to a geometric shift in river planform. Through a combination of reduced-scaled physical experiments of single-threaded river evolution in the absence of plants and field observations of Proterozoic fluvial deposits in NW Scotland, I will test the hypothesis that the Silurian-age stratigraphic shift occurred due to a kinematic shift in the rates of river evolution that was coeval with plant evolution. Specifically, I will test the hypotheses that: (1) pre-vegetation single-threaded rivers were sustained by fine-grained cohesive bank sediment but their lateral channel migration rates were an order-of-magnitude greater than their vegetated counterparts; (2) high lateral migration rates—relative to river avulsion rates—caused the rapid reworking of floodplain deposits and flushed fine-grained sediment from the fluvial realm, resulting in vertically-truncated, poorly preserved, laterally extensive bar packages and a paucity of preserved alluvial mudrock. New experimental and field data generated from this study will enable the critical evaluation of the causes and consequences of an enigmatic shift in fluvial strata that records the co-evolution of life and surface processes on our planet.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of this project, I sought to provide a mechanistic understanding of an apparent one-way shift in the character of river sediments, long associated with the emergence of land plants. I tested two hypotheses: 1) pre-vegetation rivers were supported by fine-grained, cohesive sediment, and hence displayed high lateral migration rates compared to vegetated rivers, and 2) these migration rates caused rapid reworking of floodplain and channel deposits, leading to poorly preserved river bar packages. The study leveraged 1.2-billion-year-old river strata from NW Scotland, documenting various stratigraphic features across different geologic formations. It successfully confirmed that pre-vegetation rivers could have been stabilized by mud alone. Progress was made in testing the second hypothesis, where highly mobile channels likely caused poor bar preservation. While more data and work is needed, the preliminary results from LiDAR surveys and outcrop observations provided valuable insights and groundwork for future experiments and research in modern rivers.

I presented the results of this work at meetings held by the American Geophysical Union, the European Geosciences Union, and the International Conference on Fluvial Sedimentology (AGU 2021, AGU 2022, EGU 2022, and ICFS 2023). Furthermore, I and co-authors Drs. Ganti, Whittaker, and Lamb (the latter a colleague at Caltech) published the results regarding channel bank cohesion in AGU's Geophysical Research Letters. Currently, I am in the process of preparing and uploading LiDAR surveys from the five studied formations to V3Geo, an open-source platform for the use of digital outcrop models in both education and research. Lastly, I am finalizing bar-scale and migration dynamics research for journal submission.

The project's impact in fluvial sedimentology centers around a novel synthesis of cohesion values for mixed sand-mud sediments and the distribution of shear stress along a channel's wetted perimeter. The first component presented both a proof-of-concept and case study of Proterozoic river systems, offering insights for paleohydraulic reconstructions of ancient river deposits and morphodynamic modeling of modern rivers. The second component contributed a significant dataset with high-resolution LiDAR surveys, showcasing dune to channel body scale stratigraphic architecture. Furthermore, I was able to demonstrate the successful use of iPad LiDAR capabilities for collecting research-quality geological data. The integration of digital outcrop models with classic outcrop characterization provides a robust dataset for estimating channel planform and bar preservation. This dataset holds the potential for comparative analyses of fluvial architecture in modern, barren floodplains, as well as scaled physical experiments aiming to characterize channel migration and floodplain reworking rates.

In a broader perspective, these results promise significant impacts on various disciplines, including civil engineering, water management, ecology, and planetary studies. By quantifying channel-bank cohesion in channels of varying geometries, floodplain infrastructure can be custom-engineered to local requirements and conditions. More specifically, these results and methods can inform engineers and environmental planners about bank materials and channel dimensions necessary for maintaining stable channels on degraded floodplains, whether caused by climate change, logging, agriculture, or natural disasters. Improved characterization and modeling of channel stability will enhance water management programs and help ecologists better understand the interrelationships of vegetation with channels and floodplains. Finally, these findings offer a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of single-thread channels observed on planetary surfaces that never hosted life, such as Mars or Titan.
